caption: Supporters of Tanzania's ruling Chama Cha Mapinduzi party come out on Friday to celebrate their candidate's victory in the disputed Zanzibari presidential election

result.explanation: The image shows a person who seems to be celebrating on what appears to be a political campaign vehicle.  However, there is no clear indication that this is Tanzania, the Chama Cha Mapinduzi party, or that this event relates to the Zanzibari presidential election. The clothing and setting suggest a tropical location in Africa, which is consistent with Tanzania, but not definitive.  The lack of clear party symbols or election-related materials limits certainty. Therefore, it is difficult to definitively confirm all the entities mentioned in the caption based on the visual evidence alone.

candidates.title: Tanzania poll: John Magufuli of CCM defeats Edward Lowassa
candidates.content:
Tanzania's governing CCM party candidate John Magufuli has won the presidential election with 58% of the vote, the electoral commission says.
His main rival Edward Lowassa has rejected the official results that gave him 40% of the ballots cast.
The opposition Ukawa coalition candidate earlier claimed he had won with 62% of the vote.
The elections on Sunday were the most fierce the governing party faced after 54 years in power.
Africa Live: BBC news updates
John Magufuli is celebrating his 56th birthday so the presidency is a perfect gift for him. He was never a CCM insider and confounded many when he was elected as the ruling party's presidential candidate.
As works minister in the outgoing government, Mr Magufuli was reputed to be a no-nonsense, results-driven politician. He became known as "The Bulldozer" for driving a programme to build roads across the country.
He campaigned for the presidency on a platform of hard work, and will now have to tackle far bigger problems facing the East African state. This includes constant power outages, and corruption - an issue which led to many people turning against CCM in the election.
'The Bulldozer' in profile
President Jakaya Kikwete, who is standing down after two terms in office, retweeted a CCM photo of Mr Magufuli, external and the accompanying words: "Our next Commander-in-Chief, Dr John Pombe Magufuli, the President-elect of The United Republic of Tanzania."
Abdallah Safari, vice-president of Chadema, one of the four opposition parties that make up Ukama, told the BBC that Tanzanians "have been robbed of their victory".
BBC Tanzania analyst Zuhura Yunus says the result is a big blow for Mr Lowassa after four opposition parties put their faith in him, uniting for the first time to field a single candidate.
candidates.description: Tanzania's governing party candidate John Magufuli has won Sunday's fiercely competitive presidential election with 58% of the vote, officials say.

result.explanation: The caption mentions celebrations by supporters of Tanzania's ruling party following a disputed Zanzibari election.  Source 1 focuses on the national presidential election, won by John Magufuli of the CCM party. While the article notes that the election was disputed by the opposition, it doesn't explicitly describe celebrations by CCM supporters following the Zanzibari election. The timeframe and location discrepancy makes direct corroboration difficult. The article's focus is the national election, not the separate Zanzibari one.  More information on the Zanzibari election is needed to verify the caption.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Mentions that Magufuli of the CCM party won the national presidential election, which was disputed by the opposition.  Source 1 does not mention celebrations following a Zanzibari election.  Source 1 describes the national election as "fiercely competitive".

final_result.explanation:
Both the internal and external validation checks cast doubt on the accuracy of the original caption.  The internal check highlights the lack of definitive visual evidence linking the image to the specific entities mentioned in the caption (Tanzania's ruling Chama Cha Mapinduzi party, the disputed Zanzibari presidential election). While the clothing and setting suggest a tropical African location, this is not conclusive evidence of the specific context described.  The absence of clear party symbols or election-related materials further weakens the internal validation. The internal check gives a confidence score of 7, indicating a relatively low degree of certainty. 

The external check reinforces these doubts. It points out that available sources primarily focus on the national presidential election in Tanzania, won by John Magufuli of the CCM party.  While the sources acknowledge disputes surrounding the election, there's no direct evidence of CCM supporters celebrating a victory in the Zanzibari presidential election.  The external check's confidence score of 4 also reflects this uncertainty. The focus on the national election in external sources, without details about the Zanzibari election, creates a significant discrepancy.

Considering the low confidence scores from both internal (7) and external (4) checks and the lack of corroborating evidence to link the image to the specific events described in the caption, the conclusion is that the caption is likely out of context. There is insufficient evidence to confirm that the image depicts supporters of Tanzania's ruling party celebrating their candidate's victory in the disputed Zanzibari presidential election.  The image might depict a political celebration in a tropical African country, but the specific details provided in the caption cannot be verified based on the available visual and textual evidence.  The discrepancies between the image content and caption details, compounded by the lack of supporting external evidence, lead to a low overall confidence score of 4 for the caption's accuracy.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation checks produced low confidence scores and failed to confirm the caption's accuracy.  Discrepancies exist between the image content and caption details; crucial information about the Zanzibari election is missing from available sources.
